data.text: Looking for Inflatable Sleeping Pad for Summer Months

Hi All Looking for recommendations for an inflatable sleeping pad, doesn't need to have to have a particularly high R value as I'll only really be using it during the warmer months. Needs to be friendly to the wallet! Here's a pic of my first ever build for a little attention! Spending a week cycling around France next month. Really rather excited! Cheers
I‚Äôve had pretty good luck with the klymit static v

data.author: D Gerit Slikkers

data.text: For a couple of years I've been using the Therm-a-Rest Z-Lite and I'm really happy with it. It's not inflatable, and that's precisely what I like about it: no need for repairs or worries about it puncturing. It takes up a bit more space on the bike, but it's worth it. Previously I had a self-inflatable Therm-a-Rest one, but after a year it started losing air, maybe the valve, maybe a tiny hole somewhere. I started suspecting then (and looking for alternatives) when I saw that they were offering such products along with patching kits. The Z-Lite needs no patching. I use it even when I'm not cycling. It's my regular mattress (along with a sheet and other bed stuff that I normally carry with me) when I sleep at friends' homes or when I'm hosted by Warmshowers members (instead of having them waste time and energy making a bed, washing it all just for a night or two).
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Theann Faucher Well, that might take some getting used to. I personally like sleeping on hard surfaces, it's better for my back. When I sleep on soft beds, I feel worse. I get aches from soft beds! The most important thing is that the mat insulates from cold and wet surfaces; after that you can put on more "softening" stuff like the sleeping bag, and I sleep with clothes (sleeping clothes) anyway, so that also acts as a "softening" agent. It's a personal preference, for sure, and might take some getting used to (or not) at first. To me it's similar to saddles; often people think a cushy bike seat will be more comfortable, but actually it's better when it's hard and smooth (like the leather ones, etc.) because then there is less friction, etc. It's not the same principle as the hard or firm sleeping surface; I'm just saying it's "counterintuitive" and takes some getting used to at first.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Nemo Astro Ultralight. Very compact, lightweight as the name suggests, the cover doubles as an inflatable pump. Price can vary but I found mine on sale.

data.text: Big Agne Q-Core SLX is the most comfortable pad I've ever slept on (side sleeper with a bad back). They are running about $110 here in the US right now.
data.author: Keri-Tracy Sprenger

data.text: , Absolutely the best I‚Äôve ever slept on! It‚Äôs light and packs away to nothing. I would recommend getting the inflation bag for it though‚Ä¶saves a lot of breaths!

data.text: Yep. The Pumphouse is a necessity, though the newer designs have their own included pump sack, I believe.
data.author: Keri-Tracy Sprenger

data.text: I've used many pads over the years. Thermarest is the big brand but I'm not happy with customer service I bought an ultra lite pad and didn't use it for most 3 months. I sent it in fir evaluation and was charged $20 for repair. Yhey basically smeared a bit of goop on a small puncture. I assumed they'd replace it since it was new but no. I'm currently using Big Agnes. Best thing to do is get on a few email lists and new customers usually get 15-20% off.

data.text: I am happy with my Alpkit inflatable mat. The Lidl version is nearly as good and a lot cheaper but it is not always available. I have tried a self inflating mat but it is heavier and bulkier. The foam pads are less comfortable. The inflatable mats at noisey as you toss and turn.

data.text: Self inflating ones are better, I reckon actually more comfortable, and they pack down nice an small.

data.text: On a budget - any cheap one will work but key is having something under it so it does get punctured like tarp, sleeping bag pad or thick heavy duty plastic.
data.author: Ed Melby

data.text: Add my voice to those suggesting you check out Klymit. I‚Äôve got one that I use as a less insulated alternative to my Thermarest. It‚Äôs less expensive than a lot of alternatives but still comfortable and decent quality. Packs down really small (though weighs about as much as my more insulated thermarest)
